title: AITA for making my friends sister cry?
post:
Please be nice lol. I was hanging out at my friend's (S) house last Saturday like usual. My friend's sister (E) is really weird. She'll just stare at me and when she realizes I notice she'll run off. I can't wear certain perfumes at their house because it's apparently too strong for E. 

Once E took the strings out of my hoodie so she could play with them. Apparently she thought the hoodie was hers even though she's seen me wear it multiple times. I once put some of my pads in their bathroom and I found out later that E had thrown them all away. E has also walked in on me several times when I'm using the bathroom. S & E share a bathroom and their parents removed the lock after an incident with E. It's super creepy and I've told E to knock several times.

Well this past Saturday E walked in on me again. The worst part was that she didn't leave right away. It was like she was a deer in headlights. I was so pissed y'all. I called her a creep and slammed the door shut. Just to be clear, I made sure the door wouldn't hit E before I shut it. Apparently this was very upsetting as she started having one of her famous meltdowns. 

Their mom was quick to respond and I tried to explain my side of the story. E's mom wasn't having it and even after S came to my defense I was told I would have to leave. Their mom told my mom an unfavorable account of the events. Apparently I'm antagonistic to E and I won't be allowed back over for awhile. My mom agreed with their mom's response. So now I'm 2nd guessing everything I ever did to E and wondering if I overreacted. Also, E is 10 so she's not like some toddler who doesn't know better.

Edit: I'm 15, S is 14, and E is on the spectrum

processed_comments.reasoning: The comment only asks for information about disabilities and makes no claims about OP’s behavior or need to apologize. It is brief, neutral, and somewhat constructive but offers no justification or ethical framing yet.

This comment requests ages and whether E has special needs, without judging OP’s intent, harm, empathy, or apology. It is neutral and mildly ethical in focus (special needs) but not yet argumentative or detailed.

By saying OP is not the asshole, it implies OP’s reaction to harm was understandable and not malicious, and suggests a conversation (repair/apology). It gives minimal justification and principle but is polite and behavior-focused.

The commenter leans NTA, implying OP reacted to real harm but not with bad intent, and notes possible undisclosed issues with E plus sympathy about OP’s mom, implying OP is reflective and might repair. It references context, fairness, and is respectful.

A bare "NTA" implies OP caused harm but was justified and not intentionally cruel, without commenting on empathy or apology. It has almost no reasoning or ethical articulation but is not biased or hostile.

Calling OP YTA and suggesting a pattern of rudeness implies intentional harmful behavior and lack of empathy, with no mention of apology. It gives some justification (age difference, spectrum) but uses a somewhat accusatory tone and assumptions.

The comment says OP is antagonistic to a disabled child in her own home, implying deliberate harm and low empathy, and doesn’t mention apology. It explains its verdict with principles of hospitality and disability accommodation but uses a slightly sharp tone.

The commenter stresses OP is old enough to know better and should reconsider how she treats E, implying intentional harm and lack of empathy, without suggesting apology. It clearly invokes norms about understanding autism and boundaries, though somewhat scolding.

Saying NTA and that E has issues and maybe a crush implies OP reacted to harm but not maliciously, while portraying OP as not especially empathic and not mentioning apology. Justification and principles are weak and the "issues"/crush speculation is somewhat insensitive.

Labeling ESH and criticizing OP for calling a disabled kid a creep implies intentional harm and lack of empathy, and explicitly says OP owes apology/repair. It also blames parents for poor boundary teaching, showing good justification, principle use, and fairness.

Calling E a problem and listing her behaviors frames OP as justified and not malicious but not especially empathic, with no apology expectation. It offers concrete reasoning and advice but is harsh toward the child, slightly reducing fairness.

The YTA verdict and noting OP knows E is on the spectrum imply OP knowingly caused harm and lacks empathy, without mentioning apology. It references disability understanding and suggests an alternative (hang out at OP’s house) in a fairly neutral tone.

The comment says OP should realize E doesn’t understand boundaries, implying OP’s reaction was knowingly hurtful and lacking empathy, with no apology guidance. It articulates principles about neurodivergence and suggests a practical alternative.

This is a speculative info question about a crush and makes no claims about OP’s intent, harm, empathy, or apology. It lacks justification or ethical framing and is mildly objectifying but not overtly biased.

Saying NTA and that E’s crying was shame, not OP’s fault, acknowledges harm but sees OP as justified and understanding of privacy violations, without urging apology. It clearly invokes privacy and parental responsibility, though it is somewhat harsh toward the family.

The YTA verdict and critique of calling E "weird" imply OP knowingly caused emotional harm and lacks empathy, with no mention of apology. It references neurodivergence and age-appropriate understanding in a firm but not slur-filled tone.

The commenter says OP went "nuclear" and is the asshole, implying deliberate harm and low empathy, but also notes OP’s self-reflection and that she can learn, and stresses that calling an autistic girl a creep warrants consequences, effectively implying need for repair. It thoroughly explains compassion, boundaries, and proportionality in a respectful, principled way.

The YTA judgment is based on OP’s lack of understanding for E, implying intentional harm and no empathy, and suggests OP avoid E rather than apologize. It articulates that E doesn’t know better and uses consistent, non-biased language.

Saying OP is the worst here and owes a huge apology clearly attributes intentional harm and lack of empathy, while explicitly calling for apology. It also blames parents for not teaching boundaries, showing multi-sided fairness and clear ethical principles.

Calling ESH and saying OP’s reaction was over the top acknowledges harm and suggests OP overreacted intentionally and without much empathy, but doesn’t mention apology. It also criticizes the family’s lack of coping strategies, balancing blame with clear reasoning and neutral language.

Comment says OP harmed E and was antagonistic, treats OP’s language as deliberate, portrays OP as lacking understanding, and urges apology/repair. It gives concrete reasons, references autism, is respectful and balanced, and uses nonbiased language.
Comment implies OP is being harmed but doesn’t discuss OP’s intent, empathy, or apology. It gives minimal justification and moral framing but is neutral in tone and language.

Comment states OP is an AH for known, repeated behavior and name-calling, so harm and intentionality are implied and it suggests OP should act better, akin to apologizing. It carefully assigns blame to multiple parties, cites fairness and respect, and uses constructive, unbiased language.

Comment acknowledges OP’s trauma/discomfort as real harm but doesn’t frame OP as intentionally cruel, empathic, or apologetic. It articulates norms about privacy and parental responsibility, is nuanced about all parties, and uses respectful language.

Comment affirms OP is not at fault and notes parents’ protective bias causing harm to OP, but doesn’t discuss OP’s intent, empathy, or apology. It gives some moral reasoning about parental behavior, is supportive, and language is mostly neutral though a bit vague about “kids like her.”

Comment says OP is TA for how she talks about a child, implying verbal harm and deliberate demeaning language, with no empathy or apology. Justification is brief but references disability, tone is sharp yet not slur-based, and blame is focused on OP’s wording.
Single-word verdict gives no information about harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It has no justification or principles, minimal deliberation, weak fairness, and neutral but contentless language.

Comment labels ESH and suggests changing venue, implying ongoing discomfort/harm to OP but not addressing OP’s intent, empathy, or apology. It’s very brief with little ethical reasoning but neutral and nonbiased.

Comment says OP is 100% the asshole for lacking compassion in E’s home, implying deliberate disregard and harm, with no empathy or apology. It references allowances for disability, is somewhat harsh but not slur-based, and assigns blame solely to OP.

Comment emphasizes OP’s repeated privacy violations as harmful but excuses OP’s language as age-typical, not focusing on intent, empathy, or apology. It thoroughly justifies NAH, articulates boundary and consent norms, is highly deliberative and fair, and uses careful, unbiased language.

Comment says OP is YTA for self-centeredness and bashing a disabled child, implying intentional verbal harm and lack of empathy or apology. It clearly cites disability awareness and respect, is accusatory but not slur-based, and focuses blame on OP.

Comment supports OP and suggests staying away, implying OP is being harmed but not discussing OP’s intent, empathy, or apology. It has minimal justification or ethical framing but is polite and unbiased.

Comment defends OP, saying E is a creep and doesn’t respect privacy, implying harm from E and that OP’s reaction was intentional but justified, with no focus on OP’s empathy or apology. It references privacy norms but uses somewhat harsh language toward E while avoiding slurs.

Comment says OP is NTA and stresses need for a lock and consequences, focusing on harm to OP and E needing teaching, not OP’s intent/empathy/apology. It appeals to privacy and accountability, is somewhat combative toward those excusing behavior, but mostly behavior-focused.

Comment calls OP YTA for centering herself over a neurodivergent 10-year-old and suggests she simply not visit, implying OP’s behavior is harmful and self-focused, with no empathy or apology. It notes ND status and entitlement, is concise but fair in suggesting an alternative, and uses neutral language.

Comment implies E isn’t at fault and that misunderstanding causes harm, and urges OP to seek explanation and understanding from the mother, effectively suggesting repair/apology. It articulates responsibility of parents and need for understanding, is highly constructive and fair, and uses very respectful language.

Comment says YTA because OP didn’t close the door and then blamed others, implying OP caused harm and is at fault, with no empathy or apology. Justification is brief and a bit snarky, with limited ethical framing but no biased language.

Comment says E’s autism doesn’t excuse intruding on OP’s privacy (harm) but that OP should have talked to mom instead of name-calling, implying OP mishandled things and should repair. It references boundaries and communication, is balanced and constructive, and uses neutral language.

Comment strongly defends OP, framing E’s repeated boundary violations as harmful and OP’s “creep” reaction as a valid high-adrenaline response, implying deliberate but justified reaction and not focusing on empathy/apology. It articulates norms about not walking on eggshells and long-term skills for ND kids, is detailed and mostly fair though somewhat dismissive of opposing views, and avoids slurs.

Comment says YTA because OP doesn’t understand E’s neurodivergence, implying harmful ignorance and lack of empathy or apology. It briefly invokes ND understanding as a norm, is concise and non-insulting, and uses unbiased language.

Says OP is the asshole for yelling at a 10‑year‑old autistic child, implying harm and deliberate antagonism, with no empathy or apology mentioned. Gives almost no reasoning or principles beyond age and diagnosis, and is very terse and dismissive.

Portrays OP as repeatedly antagonistic, calling E weird and yelling, thus causing harm intentionally or negligently and lacking empathy, and urges OP to educate herself and change behavior (implying need to repair). Provides detailed justification, references autism, social skills, patience, and suggests alternative behaviors in a mostly respectful, principle‑based way.

Frames OP as justified and harmed by repeated boundary violations, but notes OP doesn’t understand E and focuses blame on parents, not OP’s empathy or apology. Gives concrete reasons, invokes ongoing behavior and parental responsibility, is supportive and non‑biased.

Comment mainly explains E’s neurodivergence and sensory/processing issues without directly judging OP’s intent, harm, empathy, or apology. It lightly articulates principles about different communication styles, is neutral and non‑biased but not very detailed or applied to OP.

States parents are correct to bar OP to keep E safe, implying OP’s presence/behavior is harmful and intentional enough to warrant exclusion and that OP lacks empathy, with no repair mentioned. It clearly explains impact vs intent, safety, and suggests an alternative (invite friend over) in a balanced, respectful way.

Defends OP but labels E’s actions as like a sex offender and speculates about a crush, implying serious harm and intent while ignoring OP’s empathy/apology. Uses inflammatory, biased language and weak reasoning with little nuance or fairness.

Says OP is NTA and shifts responsibility to the mom to teach manners, implying OP was harmed but not at fault, without discussing OP’s empathy or apology. Justification is brief but points to guest etiquette; tone is neutral and non‑biased though not very developed.

Accuses OP of making E look like a pervert and calls the post ignorant, implying OP is causing reputational/emotional harm intentionally and lacks empathy, with no repair. It appeals to educating oneself about autism and suggests not sleeping over, but tone is scolding and somewhat dismissive.
Supports OP as NTA and focuses on privacy harm and a practical lock solution, without addressing OP’s empathy or apology. Reasoning is minimal but constructive and uses neutral, non‑biased language.

Calls it soft ESH, saying OP overreacted by calling E creepy (harmful, somewhat intentional, lacking empathy) and that others also erred, and implies OP should handle future incidents differently (repair/learning). It articulates norms about rudeness, intent vs impact, and parental duties in a balanced, respectful way.

Labels OP YTA for holding E’s disability against her and not talking to the mother, implying OP is repeatedly unkind and harmful, and that OP should have handled it differently (implied need to change/repair). It references disability understanding and reasonable accommodations, with some sharp but not slur‑like language.

States privacy invasion is never okay and that family isn’t teaching boundaries, so OP is harmed but not at fault, without discussing OP’s empathy or apology. It clearly invokes privacy and boundary norms, is supportive and non‑biased.

Says OP may be NTA for the incident but is TA for flippant language about meltdowns and sensory issues, implying OP is dismissive and hurtful yet should develop more sympathy (repair/learning). It explains sensory issues and judgment, balancing criticism of parents with a call for OP’s empathy, in respectful, clear terms.

Argues E’s autism doesn’t excuse her behavior and parents must intervene, so OP is harmed but not at fault, with no focus on OP’s empathy or apology. It briefly invokes accountability and parental responsibility, in neutral, non‑biased language.

Says OP is NTA and acknowledges E’s struggles, suggesting E wants to be social but doesn’t know how, implying harm to OP but not malicious intent and not really assessing OP’s empathy/apology. It balances understanding for both sides and uses respectful, non‑biased language.

Supports OP as NTA and calls E’s behavior not normal, advising OP to stay away, implying OP is harmed but not at fault, without discussing empathy or apology. Justification is brief and somewhat pathologizing but not overtly slur‑like.

Backs OP as NTA, emphasizes repeated bathroom invasions as unacceptable harm and blames parents for enabling, without addressing OP’s empathy/apology. It offers practical advice (talk to mom) and uses neutral, non‑biased language.

Says YTA and that OP must deal with E differently because she’s on the spectrum, implying OP is treating her poorly and causing harm, but doesn’t mention apology or empathy explicitly. It’s very short with minimal reasoning, though language is not slur‑based.

States OP is NTA but stresses the importance of actively teaching behavior, especially for neurodivergent kids, implying OP was harmed but not at fault, without judging OP’s empathy/apology. It articulates principles about learning social norms and is constructive and unbiased.

Calls OP YTA for dismissing an autistic child’s needs and reacting harshly, describing multiple ways OP criticizes and gets mad at E, implying ongoing harm and lack of empathy, with no apology mentioned. It clearly applies principles of kindness, accommodation, and perspective‑taking in a detailed, respectful, non‑biased way.

Comment says E’s behaviors are wrong and harmful and should have been corrected, implying deliberate allowance of harm and no apology from OP. It clearly justifies NTA with a disability/accommodation principle and is respectful and unbiased.

Comment treats OP as justified and harmed and suggests practical boundary protections, implying E’s actions are ongoing and intentional enough to guard against. It gives some reasoning and advice but little explicit ethical framing, and language is neutral and fair.

Comment acknowledges OP’s discomfort as harm but frames E’s behavior as part of her safe space rather than intentional malice and urges OP to adjust context. It offers a balanced NAH view with some principle of respecting space, is constructive and unbiased.

Comment states E invades privacy and is being set up for social rejection and exploitation, indicating real harm and that parents knowingly allow it. It grounds NTA in privacy and protection principles, is detailed and respectful toward OP and E, and avoids biased language.

Comment calls the situation disturbing and says parents don’t respect OP’s reasonable boundaries, implying clear harm and intentional disregard. It briefly justifies NTA with autonomy/privacy principles and uses neutral, nonbiased language.

Comment labels the child a “creepy ass kid,” implying harmful behavior and blame but without nuance about intent or repair. It gives minimal justification, uses insulting and biased tone toward a disabled child, and is not deliberative or fair.

Comment asserts OP is an asshole for not understanding the illness but doesn’t clearly discuss harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It lacks explanation or principles, is dismissive, and only mildly neutral in language.

Comment validates OP’s feelings as understandable harm but stresses E isn’t doing it to annoy and processes differently, and urges OP to have empathy and accept the visit ban as appropriate. It articulates autism, empathy, and family-burden principles with high deliberative quality and fair, unbiased tone.

Comment notes OP’s discomfort and suggests avoiding E, implying ongoing harm but not intentional malice, and calls NAH. It offers practical advice with some balance but little explicit moral framing, and language is neutral.

Comment says losing cool was a mistake and that OP should expect E’s behavior, recognizing harm but not focusing on intent or empathy, and notes mom’s boundary. It explains the dynamics and consequences reasonably and respectfully with neutral language.
Comment supports NTA, advises OP not to return and to state discomfort, implying real harm and that the family knowingly allows it. It briefly justifies boundaries and is constructive and unbiased.

Comment affirms NTA and suggests avoiding the shared bathroom or house, implying ongoing harmful boundary violations. It gives practical advice with minimal principle articulation and neutral language.
Single-word NTA gives no information about harm, intent, empathy, or apology. It has almost no justification or principles but is neutral and not biased.

Comment says OP is not the asshole and criticizes E’s mother’s handling, implying OP was harmed but not focusing on intent or empathy. It references parental responsibility and is respectful and unbiased.
